title: PUBLIC ACCESS PRAYERS
words:
Public Access Prayers

                      Your pastoral prayer, for some, may be their 
only connection to the power of the
                      Almighty.

                      Dave Wiersbe

                      One Sunday after worship, a first-time guest 
said to me, "I appreciated
                      the pastoral prayer." I forget my response. I 
was stunned to learn that
                      someone cared about that part of the service. 
Someone besides God.
                      Since then I've learned how important the 
pastoral prayer is.

                      A few years ago, Leadership printed a cartoon 
with a pastor greeting
                      people after the church service. He spies the 
man next in line to shake
                      his hand. The cartoonist takes us into the 
pastor's thoughts: "Oh, no!
                      There's Bob. I told him last week I'd be 
praying for him and I forgot!
                      Dear Lord, bless Bob. Amen."

                      Then the pastor says, "Hi, Bob! How are you? 
Been prayin' for you!"

                      As I look across the faces in the congregation, 
I wonder how many
                      Bobs are out there. How many people long to be 
prayed for, but don't
                      know the comfort of hearing another believer 
speak their need to the
                      Lord?

                      I want our people to know they are prayed for. 
And I want them to
                      experience the peace of resting under the 
prayers of a pastor who
                      takes seriously the charge to carry them before 
God's throne. One of
                      the best ways is through the pastoral prayer on 
Sunday morning.

                      I mean it.

                      I discovered early in my ministry that my 
"spontaneous" pastoral
                      prayer began sounding repetitious. Even the 
offertory prayer grew
                      redundant: "Bless these gifts and use them to 
your glory."

                      If the congregation was to know the depths of 
my heart in praying for
                      them, then I needed to replace the routine of 
ad lib prayers with a
                      fresher approach. So I sought out resources.

                      The prayers in Scripture offer a rich source of 
proven ways to approach
                      God. Psalm 66:20 grabbed my attention during 
devotions, and I traced
                      the phrase "Blessed be God" through the other 
psalms.

                      The next Sunday I began the first six 
statements of the pastoral prayer
                      with, "Blessed be God," followed by a reason 
for blessing him.

                      After worship a woman came up and grabbed my 
hand. She said that
                      she had prayed on the way to church for that 
morning's service to be
                      different. "When you began the prayer with, 
'Blessed be God,' my
                      heart soared. I knew God heard my prayer."

                      On the first Easter we scheduled two worship 
services, I did not have
                      lots of time for a rambling extemporaneous 
prayer. Every word had to
                      count. How could I make the prayer communicate 
the joy, power, and
                      wonder of the Resurrection?

                      A pastor friend had loaned me The Book of 
Common Worship so I'd
                      know the liturgy for the community Good Friday 
service. I lifted some
                      ideas for my Easter prayer. Our invocation that 
morning began,
                      "Rejoice, heavenly powers! Sing, choirs of 
angels! Exult, all creation
                      around God's throne! Jesus Christ our King is 
risen!" In the pastoral
                      prayer I adapted words from the ancient Prayer 
of Adoration: "Glory to
                      you, O God; you have defeated death, raising 
Jesus from the grave,
                      and giving us eternal life. Glory to you, Risen 
Lord; for us and for our
                      salvation you overcame death and opened the 
gate to everlasting life."

                      Those words had never been used in our church, 
and the response
                      was electric. People listened. People 
responded. Most were glad for
                      the vitality of carefully chosen words.

                      So I plan it

                      From those experiences I began to plan my 
pastoral prayer.

                      Usually I complete my sermon preparation on 
Saturday evening. Then
                      I work on the prayer. I refer to our Thursday 
night prayer list to remind
                      me of those persons with specific needs. I also 
list the situations
                      different families find themselves in: our 
farmers need rain; families are
                      grieving the death of a loved one; marriages 
are strained; one family is
                      about to adopt a baby, while another family has 
suffered miscarriage.

                      I do not mention anyone by name unless I have 
their permission.
                      Some situations are too sensitive to identify, 
so I pray for "persons
                      facing" specific issues (those in need of work, 
those who feel the
                      absence of a loved one, those who struggle with 
depression).

                      Almost every pastoral prayer also includes 
intercession for our
                      national, state, or local leaders, for at least 
one of our missionary
                      families, and for one of the other churches in 
town. Mentioning another
                      church and pastor by name heightens awareness 
of the breadth of
                      God's work in the world.

                      Once the intercessions have taken shape, I 
shape the bookends of the
                      prayer. Beginning with the address, I search 
Psalms and Epistles for
                      unique names for God. The language of address 
informs the words of
                      praise and adoration that follow.

                      If I begin with "God the Father, Son, and Holy 
Spirit," I direct an
                      ascription of praise to each person.

                      If the address is to "Our Lord Jesus," I may 
refer to his authority as
                      Head of the Church, then invoke him as Good 
Shepherd when praying
                      for those who grieve.

                      Here is a favorite expression of adoration: "O 
God, let us rise to the
                      edges of time and open our lives to eternity. 
Let us run to the edges of
                      space and gaze into your immensity. Let us 
climb past the barriers of
                      sound and enter your silence; and then, in 
stillness and silence, let us
                      adore You, who are Light, Life, Love, without 
beginning, and without
                      end" (from The Oxford Book of Prayer).

                      Before moving into the intercessory prayers, I 
reserve a moment to
                      address spiritual issues. If the church family 
is facing a test of faith, I
                      may adapt the words of St. Anselm: "We desire 
to understand a little
                      of your truth which our hearts already believe 
and love. We do not
                      seek to understand so that we can believe, but 
we believe so that we
                      may understand."

                      Finally I work on the closing, often drawing on 
the season. In Advent I
                      might say, "We pray in the name of him whose 
coming is certain,
                      whose day draws near. As the saints long have 
prayed, so we now
                      pray: Come quickly, Lord Jesus." At Easter, "in 
the name of our risen
                      Lord and Savior Jesus Christ we pray."

                      The Book of Common Worship has several prayers 
for each Sunday
                      of the year, based on the lectionary passages. 
Especially for Advent,
                      Lent, and Easter, these prayers offer both 
variety and a unifying theme
                      for the service.

                      If there is any part of the prayer that I still 
repeat often, it's the Amen. I
                      like to end my public prayers with the phrase 
from Psalm 106:48, "and
                      all of God's people said," to which 
congregations never fail to respond,
                      "Amen." It allows the congregation to 
participate and verbally affirm
                      what's been prayed.

                      The final form of the pastoral prayer may last 
four to seven minutes,
                      and I do not write out every word. The address 
and adoration are
                      mainly phrases, the petitions simply listed, 
and the closing is as full
                      as I need. On most Sunday mornings I learn of 
other requests and jot
                      them on my prayer guide.

                      Every Sunday, I want the whole flock to know 
their pastor is taking
                      seriously his charge to lift them before the 
Great Shepherd.


title: PLANET EARTH IN 2002
words:
the statistics compiled
   by Associate Press writer John Jurgensen this past week. They
   certainly help define reality and where we are as people on
   Planet Earth in 2002.

   Population of the world: 6.1 billion.

   Life expectancy at birth: 64.6 (male), 68.6 (female)

   Adult literacy rate: 75.7 percent

   Estimated total living languages: 6,809

   Most widely spoken language: Mandarin, 1.1 billion people

   Rank of English among languages spoken by the most people:
   4th, 514 million speakers

   Number of people who live on less than $1 a day: 1.2 billion,
   or one fifth.

   Number of volcanoes considered active, having erupted in the
   last 10,000 years: 1,511

   Earthquakes of a magnitude of 7.0 or greater in 2001: 15

   Deaths caused by earthquakes in 2001: 21,436

   Number of countries that endured war or other serious conflict
   in 2001: 59

   Number of people living with HIV/AIDS: 40 million

   Number of new HIV infections each day in 2001: 14,000

   These numbers give us a glimpse of our world. Amid these grim
   statistics, it's easy to be fearful and anxious, but they also
   bring to mind the words of Jesus: "When you hear of wars and
   rumors of wars, do not be alarmed. Such things must happen,
   but the end is still to come. Nation will rise against nation,
   and kingdom against kingdom. There will be earthquakes in
   various places and famines. These are the beginning of birth
   pains. You must be on your guard... All men will hate you
   because of me, but he who stands firm to the end will be
   saved" (Mark 13: 7-13).

   Two other statistics also caught my eye in the AP list:

   Estimated number of distinct religions: 10,000

   Denominations within Christianity alone: 33,830.

   Many people look at those numbers and are tempted to say, "All
   religions are the same. It doesn't matter what you believe.
   I'm a spiritual person, but I'm not going to practice any
   specific religion." Amid that muddy thinking, George
   Santayana's clear-eyed observation provides an antidote: "To
   attempt to be religious without practicing a specific religion
   is as possible as attempting to speak without a specific
   language."

   Whichever way you're facing-past or future-may God grant you
   wisdom and power in leading people to Jesus in 2002.

   --Marshall Shelley is editor of Leadership. To reply, write to
   Newsletter@LeadershipJournal.net.

title: PETER, JAMES, AND JOHN
words:
Peter, James and John

G.C. Morgan wrote concerning the special three: "There can be no 
doubt that
these men, Peter, James, and John, were the most remarkable in the
apostolate. Peter loved Him; John He loved; James was the first to 
seal his
testimony with his blood. Even their blunders proved their strength. 
They
were the men of enterprise; men who wanted thrones and places of
power...Mistaken ideas, all of them, and yet proving capacity for 
holding
the keys and occupying the throne. What men from among that first 
group
reign today as these men?

On four special occasions, Jesus admitted them to experiences from 
which
they learned precious lessons. On the occasion of the raising of 
Jairus's
daughter (Luke 8:51), they were granted a preview of their Lord's 
mastery
over death ... On the mount of transfiguration (Matt 17:1), they 
gained
clearer insight into the importance of His impending death ... On the 
Mount
of Olives (Mark 13:3), they marveled at His prophetic discernment ... 
In the
Garden of Gethsemane (Matt 26:37), they glimpsed in the sufferings of 
the
Savior something of the cost of their salvation..."

title: PLAYING AGAINST TYPE
words:
RICHARD NIXON

                                                                                      
Playing against type 

                      Richard Nixon called it "the week that changed 
the world." Thirty years ago, on Feb.
                      21, 1972, Air Force One flew into Beijing 
airport. Nixon stepped off the plane alone and
                      reached for the hand of China's premier, Zhou 
Enlai. The handshake, captured live on
                      prime-time American television, dramatized an 
end to decades of U.S.-Chinese
                      hostilityand to the isolation of the world's 
most populous nation.

                      It also dramatized something else: a 
president's power to change the course of
                      history by playing against type. An ardent 
anti-Communist, Nixon  had mastered the
                      bruising art of bashing Reds and liberals 
purported to be soft on communism. Nixon
                      understood perfectly how his past made room to 
maneuver. He confided to Mao
                      Zedong, China's frail paramount leader, that  
"those on the right can do what those on the 
                      left can only talk about." Mao's view: "I like 
rightists."

                      The term "Nixon goes to China" became a 
political clichbut also a model for action:
                      By spending hard-won political capital, a 
leader could turn the world upside down. Of
                      course, the original was hard to top; when a 
pro-labor Bill Clinton campaigned for a
                      free-trade pact with Mexico, the sideline 
strategists explained that he'd pulled a "Nixon
                      goes to China." 

                      Perhaps. But Nixon wasn't lying when he boasted 
about changing the world. Just
                      before taking office, he told Henry Kissinger, 
soon to be national security adviser, that
                      he wanted to rethink a China policy frozen by 
the Cold War. The president and
                      Kissinger, practitioners of an unsentimental 
realpolitik, felt closer ties with Beijing could
                      tip the global balance of power in America's 
favor. By building a bridge to China, Nixon
                      believed, America would win leverage over 
Moscow and perhaps even break China's
                      "angry isolation." What Nixon foresaw all came 
to pass. Moscow, alarmed by the
                      opening to China, chose to pursue its own 
dtente with Nixon. American and Chinese
                      diplomats hashed out the Shanghai Communiqu, a 
blueprint for full normalization of
                      ties. It so successfully finessed the delicate 
issue of Taiwan that it remains policy to
                      this day. 

                      Nixon's penchant for secrecy pervaded the 
lead-up to the summit. The initial diplomatic
                      probings were conducted clandestinelyand 
largely excluded the State Department,
                      which Nixon suspected would leak to the press 
and resist change. Secret channels of
                      communication to Beijing were opened through 
the Pakistani and Romanian
                      governments. Although Nixon mused publicly 
about his desire to visit China someday
                      and even eased trade and travel restrictions 
with the mainland, China-watchers
                      missed what was coming. By the summer of 1971, 
the secret contacts had landed an
                      invitation for Kissinger to visit the Chinese 
capital. On a visit to Pakistan, he faked a
                      stomach ailment and dropped out of sight of 
reporters, then flew to China on a
                      Pakistani jet. Kissinger sent Nixon a 
prearranged one-word message to signal
                      success: "Eureka." Four days later, on July 15, 
Nixon stunned Americans by
                      announcing that he would go to China.

                      Nixon devoted himself to making the trip a 
television extravaganza. His advance team
                      ensured that journalists would be fed a full 
menu of striking images of the Nixons at
                      the Forbidden City, the Great Wall, and the 
extravagant banquetsbut not the details of
                      the negotiations. A burly staffer blocked 
advisers (including Kissinger) from exiting Air
                      Force One so that only Nixon would be 
immortalized in pictures of the first handshake
                      with Chou. 

                      Most of the careful scripting worked, but 
moments of unintended humor crept in
                      anyway. There were the Nixons uneasily soaking 
up a revolutionary operaThe Red
                      Detachment of Womenstaged by the fanatical 
wife of Mao, Chiang Ching. When
                      asked his opinion of the Great Wall, Nixon 
answered, earnestly: "This is a great wall."
                      At the farewell banquet in Shanghai, the leader 
of the Western world seemed to get
                      tipsy from mao-tai, China's sorghum firewater. 
After many toasts, an unusually gushy
                      Nixon seemed to offer a U.S. guarantee to 
protect China from attack. He didn't mean to.

                      Still, as Nixon flew home in triumph, the mood 
on Air Force One was oddly subdued.
                      He brooded over the expected media criticisms 
and conservative backlash. Back in the
                      Oval Office, Nixon felt compelled to embellish 
the breakthrough. Kissinger sensed "a
                      lack of assurance even during his greatest 
accomplishments"one of the character
                      flaws that would sink Nixon's presidency. "It 
was," Kissinger wrote in his memoirs,
                      "the psychological essence of the Watergate 
debacle." -Thomas Omestad
                      U.S. News and World Report

title: POWER, PERIL, AND CONFLICT
words:
On the Job
                                                        Four former 
presidents on power, peril, and conflict 
       
                     BY KENNETH T. WALSH

                     Gerald Ford | Jimmy Carter | Ronald Reagan | 
George Herbert Walker Bush | Bill Clinton 

                     It was one of the most humiliating images of the 
past 30 years: Thousands of
                     Vietnamese civilians, including frail old men 
and weeping mothers with terrified infants,
                     clawed their way to the tops of buildings and 
climbed fences to reach the U.S.
                     Embassy in Saigon. They were making a final, 
desperate bid for their lives, hoping for
                     evacuation by helicopter as Communist forces 
marched into the besieged capital of
                     South Vietnam. The date: April 29, 1975. The 
pictures brought home some painful
                     realities: The war in Vietnam was lost, 
America's sense of invincibility shattered. The
                     nation's confidence lay trampled in the steaming 
rice paddies of Southeast Asia.

                     If the fall of Saigon represented an America in 
decline, a more recent imageof
                     the three rescue workers raising Old Glory amid 
the rubble of the World Trade
                     Centershows a nation resolved, a people sure of 
their triumph over the terrorists 
                     President Bush calls "the evildoers."

                     Those two images  bracket the past three 
decades. Much of the
                     credit or blame for the history of that era can 
be attributed to the six presidents who
                     have led the country since the mid-1970sGerald 
Ford, Jimmy Carter, Ronald Reagan,
                     George Herbert Walker Bush, Bill Clinton, and, 
today, George W. Bush. Only twice
                     before have there been as many as five living 
ex-presidentsonce at the start of
                     Abraham Lincoln's administration and again at 
the start of Bill Clinton's first term.
                     Scholars will be assessing their performance for 
years to come, but the former
                     presidents have their own ideas about what it 
takes to be an effective leader in times
                     of crisis. For the first time, four of the five 
living ex-presidents, Ford, Carter, Bush, and
                     Clinton, granted separate interviews to a news 
organizationU.S. Newsto discuss
                     presidential leadership over the past three 
decades. President Reagan, afflicted with
                     Alzheimer's disease, was unable to participate, 
but Nancy Reagan and several of his
                     former senior aides, including Michael Deaver 
and Ken Duberstein, spoke on his
                     behalf.

                     Three of the six presidents led wars during 
their time in office: Ford in Vietnam,
                     George H. W. Bush in the Persian Gulf, and, now, 
George W. Bush in Afghanistan.
                     The other three ordered a number of military 
operations during their tenures. In April
                     1980, Carter approved a controversial mission to 
rescue American hostages in
                     Tehran, Iran, that ended in disaster. Ronald 
Reagan ordered a successful invasion of
                     Grenada and rid the tiny Caribbean island of the 
radical Marxists who took over in
                     October 1983. Reagan hadn't been as lucky when 
he sent marines into Lebanon to
                     show American resolve through military forcea 
centerpiece of his foreign policy; the
                     Marine compound at Beirut International Airport 
was bombed on Oct. 23, 1983; 241
                     Americans were killed. In 1993, Clinton 
broadened America's intervention in Somalia,
                     which he inherited from Bush, resulting in the 
deaths of several American soldiers;
                     one of their corpses was dragged through the 
streets of Mogadishu. Clinton also
                     ordered various if limited bombing campaigns in 
the former Yugoslavia and launched
                     strikes against terrorists more than once, never 
with overwhelmingly successful
                     results.

                     What makes an effective commander in chief? 
"First and foremost, he needs to come
                     up with an effective strategy for winning the 
war," says presidential historian Robert
                     Dallek. "Woodrow Wilson and Franklin Roosevelt 
were examples of presidents who
                     succeeded on that count. Harry Truman and Lyndon 
Johnson, on the other hand, had
                     stumbling and failed war strategies. Second, you 
need to have a long-term vision of
                     what to do with your victory . . . of how to win 
the peace. Here, Wilson was the
                     greatest visionary in the history of the 
country," even though his notion of a League of
                     Nations was too far ahead of its time.

                     Unfortunately, Dallek says, none of the past 
five presidents or the current commander
                     in chief measures up very well as a visionary.

                     Yet all the former presidents interviewed give a 
more complex definition than Dallek's
                     or most other historians' of what makes an 
effective commander in chief. Most
                     decisions made under life-and-death 
circumstances can't be so neatly dissected, they
                     say. All mention the ability to set a clear 
mission, to establish the rightness of
                     America's cause, to demonstrate resolve, and to 
persuade America and key allies to
                     support administration policies. And there was 
general agreement that leadership in a
                     foreign-policy crisis can be easier, or at least 
less complicated, than leadership in
                     peacetime or on domestic affairs because a 
president can act unilaterally in an
                     international crisis. "The domestic situation is 
infinitely more difficult," Carter says,
                     "because when a president launches a war, 
justified or not, he immediately becomes
                     the commander in chief and the leader of young 
men and women overseas whose
                     lives are in danger and who are sacrificing to 
accomplish a national goal. Whereas
                     when you are immersed in the details of 
administration . . . that's when you lose the
                     image of a decisive commander in chief and you 
become, in effect, more like a prime
                     minister. . . . So there is quite a lot of 
difference there."

                     Vice President Dick Cheney, who has seen his 
share of international crises over the
                     years as an adviser to three presidents, also 
sees a significant difference between
                     presidential leadership during peacetime and 
war. "It centers on the role of commander
                     in chief," Cheney says. "A lot of what a 
president does is to exercise shared
                     responsibilitymost of the time, with Congress, 
whether it's getting a budget approved
                     or a major piece of legislation authorized. When 
you get into the military arena and
                     you've deployed forces and you're having to make 
command decisions, in effect, as
                     commander in chief, that's not a shared 
responsibility."

                     "You've got to bring the Congress along," adds 
Cheney, former defense secretary
                     under George H. W. Bush and White House chief of 
staff for Ford. ". . . But it's much
                     more that everybody understands you look to the 
president to make those basic,
                     fundamental, key decisionswhen to deploy, how 
to deploy, and to approve your
                     overall strategy on when to decide to use 
military forceand to get the mix right
                     between military force and diplomacy and 
intelligence activities."

                     Bill Clinton says leadership in a foreign crisis 
is challenging in a special way. "For one
                     thing," he observes, "the people you're dealing 
with are different and the options for
                     compromise may be much more limited, and so the 
consequences of a mistake may be
                     far greater. The job largely consists of, it 
seems to me, No. 1, having a vision of where
                     we are, a clear understanding of where we are, 
and a good vision of where you think
                     America ought to go. Coming up with a strategy 
to get there and then implementing it.
                     And you know, doing what you ran for office to 
do."

                     The presidents agree that a commander in chief 
is frequently defined by unexpected
                     events. Presidents who lead in times of peace 
and prosperity, like Clinton, rarely have
                     the chance to demonstrate their leadership 
capabilities to the fullest. And even those
                     who provide effective wartime leadership, like 
George H. W. Bush, don't automatically
                     get re-elected. If they fail to connect with 
voters over domestic issues, especially
                     during an economic downturn, they run into 
trouble.

                     Yet former President Bush says domestic politics 
had nothing to do with his decision
                     to stand and fight. Not only did the Persian 
Gulf War drive Iraq out of Kuwait, he
                     argues, but it also helped make the case for 
U.S. military engagement around the
                     world. "It did restore faith in our military 
after Vietnam," Bush says. ". . . People saw
                     that the smart bombs were smart, and there were 
far less casualties than some
                     predicted . . . and we were fighting for the 
right reasons."

                     In the future, the challenges will only get more 
complicated, Carter says: "The United
                     States has now become, for the first time since 
the Roman Empire, maybe even before
                     then, the dominant military and political 
factor, maybe economic factor, on Earth . . . .
                     How we handle that new enormous power in a 
responsible and benevolent way is a
                     challenge that we have not faced. . . . I think 
it would be a mistake for us to become
                     arrogant, or rely too easily on our own military 
power, or to ignore the legitimate needs
                     of people around the world."

                     Gerald Ford (1974-77). In many ways, Ford was 
dealt the most difficult hand of any
                     president in the past three decades. As a 
Republican congressman from Grand
                     Rapids, Mich., he never sought the presidency; 
Richard Nixon named him vice
                     president after his original running mate, Spiro 
Agnew, resigned amid a corruption
                     scandal. Ford succeeded to the presidency in 
August 1974, after Nixon resigned
                     during the Watergate investigation.

                     Ford inherited the Vietnam War, approaching its 
messy conclusion. He had to cope
                     with massive disaffection at home, not only 
against the war but against politics,
                     government, capitalism, and traditional 
morality. Children seemed to be turning against
                     their parents, blacks against whites, women 
against men, region against region,
                     liberals against conservatives. America appeared 
to be approaching a nervous
                     breakdown, and the pundits wondered if the 
presidency was too big a job for one
                     individual.

                     At first, Ford seemed ill-prepared for the White 
House. Saturday Night Live mocked him
                     as a klutz barely able to walk and talk at the 
same time. But the caricature bore little
                     resemblance to the man, a Yale Law School 
graduate, a leader in Congress, and a
                     lifelong athlete. It was on an issue of 
political morality that Ford ran into his deepest
                     trouble. Believing the nation was becoming 
unhinged by the endless recriminations
                     over Nixon's behavior, he decided the best 
course was to pardon his predecessor of
                     all crimes and hope the nation would move on. 
Ford was castigated at the time, and
                     the Nixon pardon was a big reason he lost his 
bid for election to Jimmy Carter in 1976.

                     Today, however, Ford is serene about the 
decision. He speaks emotionally of his deep
                     gratitude to Sen. Ted Kennedy and other members 
of the Kennedy family for awarding
                     him a "profile in courage" award last year for 
granting the pardon under such difficult
                     conditions. "It was a great big thrill," Ford 
says. "You have no idea. The criticism was
                     so sharp when I did it, and to have these 
distinguished people publicly indicating how
                     they felt, it was a wonderful vindication."

                     Looking back on the past 30 years, Ford told 
U.S. News: "I do feel that absolute
                     integrity is a cornerstone of a successful 
presidency. Integrity, character . . . . In
                     addition, I think there is a great benefit for a 
president to have . . . experience,
                     exposure to the issues, domestic and 
international. I'm a little prejudiced. I think it's
                     understood. I think that Congress is the great 
training ground for a president, at least it
                     certainly was in my case.''



                     Jimmy Carter (1977-81). Campaigning as a simple 
peanut farmer who promised
                     never to tell a lie, Carter narrowly defeated 
Ford in 1976. The former Democratic
                     governor of Georgia went on to endure his own 
trials and tribulations before being
                     ousted by Ronald Reagan in 1980. "We had some 
very dangerous times when I was
                     president," Carter says. "We tried to bring 
peace to other people as much as we
                     possibly could, and human rights was a basic 
foundation of our entire foreign policy.
                     We never found a need to drop a bomb or launch a 
missile . . . . I have to say, as
                     commander I chief, I would have done so if I 
thought the security of my country was
                     involved. But I think the restraint on ourselves 
and our tremendous power is the
                     biggest challenge of the future."

                     Carter was surprised by the Soviet Union's 
invasion of Afghanistan in 1979. When
                     Iranian revolutionaries seized more than 50 
Americans on Nov. 4, 1979, and held them
                     hostage for more than a year, he seemed weak and 
ineffective. But most important to
                     voters was his failure to reduce the sense of 
disaffection and decline that had
                     plagued Ford for his 21/2 years in the White 
House. The economy tanked; inflation hit
                     double digits. Long gas lines left many 
Americans feeling life was spinning out of
                     control.



                     Ronald Reagan (1981-89). Reagan arguably 
established the clearest and most
                     successful style of leadership in the past 30 
years. The oldest man ever to serve as
                     president (he turned 70 about two weeks after he 
was sworn in), he set a handful of
                     big objectivesrolling back communism, cutting 
taxes, curbing government growthand
                     won over the country with his sunny optimism. He 
also scared lots of people with his
                     hard-line rhetoric, including his denunciation 
of the Soviet Union as an "evil empire"
                     bent on dominating the world.

                     The former GOP governor of California showed 
considerable grace under pressure
                     two months after his inauguration, when he was 
shot by John Hinckley Jr. on March
                     30, 1981. Near death, he insisted on walking 
into the hospital from his limousine, only
                     to sink to one knee after he stepped through the 
door. "He believed it was part of the
                     role of the president of the United States to 
show strength and confidence to the
                     American people," recalls Michael Deaver. "You 
never saw weakness."

                     From then on, Reagan saw himself as a man of 
destiny. He believed he was spared
                     for a reasonto pursue his conservative agenda. 
But he had mixed results. His
                     enormous tax cuts and his huge defense buildup 
helped swell the budget deficit, but
                     the economy boomed and communism unraveled. He 
got into trouble with the
                     Iran-contra affair, an overzealous attempt to 
aid anti-Marxist rebels in Nicaragua by
                     sending them the profits from arms sales to 
Iran. But he made unexpected progress in
                     improving East-West relations.

                     In fact, his relationship with Soviet leader 
Mikhail Gorbachev was historic in ending the
                     tensions between Washington and Moscow. Both 
arrived on the scene at precisely
                     the right moment, with solid political support 
at home and enough energy and political
                     will to move the East-West relationship to a 
new, cooperative phase.

                     Former advisers like Deaver and Duberstein say 
it was Reagan's clarity of purpose
                     that was his biggest strength. His wife, who 
knows him best, agrees. "Obviously,"
                     she told U.S. News, "Ronnie had tremendous 
communication skills, but I've always
                     believed that his clear sense of himself and his 
steadfastness to a set of principles
                     were his greatest asset." That made all the 
difference.



                     George Herbert Walker Bush (1989-93). Bush was 
elected as Reagan's heir,
                     although he pledged a "kinder, gentler" 
administration to soften some of Reagan's
                     hard-edged policies. His brand of Republican 
conservatism was stymied by a
                     Democratic-controlled Congress, but he faced his 
biggest challenge in 1990 when Iraq
                     invaded Kuwait, threatening to destabilize the 
Mideast and disrupt the West's oil
                     supplies. The resulting Persian Gulf War was a 
huge success for the United States
                     and its allies. The Iraqis were pushed out of 
Kuwait in a 100-hour ground assault, and
                     Americans were overjoyed. But dictator Saddam 
Hussein remained in powerand is
                     still reigning today to plague Bush's son.

                     Still, the elder Bush was an effective wartime 
leader. Unlike on domestic issues,
                     where he seemed adrift and sometimes 
uninterested, he was fully engaged in the
                     war. Bush was able to rally a divided country 
and Congressa vital part of wartime
                     leadership. He defined a clear mission and 
emphasized the justice of the American
                     effortmuch as George W. Bush is doing today in 
fighting the terrorist threat. Despite
                     his vast experience in foreign affairs as 
Reagan's vice president and, before that,
                     director of central intelligence and U.S. 
ambassador to the United Nations, the elder
                     Bush delegated large amounts of authority to 
talented subordinates, including then
                     Gen. Colin Powell and then Defense Secretary 
Dick Cheney. It was, in some ways, a
                     textbook war.

                     Bush told U.S. News his role as commander in 
chief was one of the most rewarding
                     parts of being president. "There's the awful 
feeling of being responsible for someone's
                     life," he says, but he adds that the cause was 
just and the outcome was successful,
                     with minimal U.S. casualties.



                     Bill Clinton (1993-2001). He swept into the 
White House as one of the youngest
                     presidents in U.S. history, with seemingly 
unlimited promise. Clinton had been a quick
                     study as the Democratic governor of Arkansas, 
and he showed during his campaign
                     that he was one of the smartest and most nimble 
politicians ever to run for the White
                     House.

                     But his record was, to put it mildly, mixed. His 
biggest slide began in January 1998
                     when the Monica Lewinsky story broke. Despite 
his impeachment by the House, he
                     presided over a huge economic boom, and his 
centrist domestic policies were widely
                     popular. 

                     Clinton never faced a sustained foreign-policy 
crisis or a war, but he did deal several
                     times with tense international situations. He 
ordered bombing missions in Iraq, and in
                     the spring of 1999 he ordered U.S. forces to 
lead a largely successful, 11-week
                     NATO bombing campaign in the former Yugoslavia 
to deter repression of ethnic
                     Albanians in Kosovo. Clinton always used 
military force, he said, as a last resortand
                     made that clear to the troops before he sent 
them into combat: "When you ask them to
                     do that, [you want them to know] that you have 
exhausted other reasonable
                     alternatives and that you have done everything 
you can to make sure that this is the
                     only available course and that the price of not 
doing it is far greater than the price of
                     proceeding."

                     President Bush's challenge today, Clinton says, 
is to cope with an era of new
                     complexities. "We live in a very different world 
than we lived in when President Ford
                     took office," he says. "While we are more 
dominant than we were 30 years ago, we
                     also in some ways are more vulnerable, as we 
have seen.'' That, of course, is the sad
                     lesson that George W. Bush learned, in the most 
traumatic way, on September 11.
                     U.S. News and World Report

title: POWER AND THE AMERICAN PRESIDENTS
words:
Special Report: Power & the 
American Presidents

                                                                
SECOND ACTS 

                      Gerald Ford spent several years after leaving 
office making money on the lucrative
                      lecture circuit. He told friends he had never 
earned much as a public servant and
                      wanted to take care of his family properly. He 
succeeded, and today he and his wife,
                      Betty, live comfortably in posh Rancho Mirage, 
Calif. Ford is probably the most serene
                      of the living ex-presidents. At 88, he is in 
remarkably good health and enjoys his
                      mostly apolitical life, rarely commenting on 
policy or granting interviews. One
                      exception: his behind-the-scenes effort to find 
a compromise that would have avoided
                      the impeachment of President Clinton. Calling 
for censure instead, he hoped to avoid a
                      partisan brawl; the effort failed. Over the 
years, he has forged a close friendship with
                      Jimmy Carter, even helping his former adversary 
monitor elections around the world.
                      -K.T.W.

                      Jimmy Carter always sought to promote peace as 
president, which led critics to call him
                      naive. Now he has found peace of mind as a 
private citizen by devoting himself to
                      good works around the world. Nearly everyone 
agrees that Carter, 77, has become a 
                      fabulous ex-president. He is the author of 
several successful books,  including his latest
                      account, An Hour  Before Daylight: Memories of 
a Rural Boyhood. He told U.S. News that 
                      book writing is his main source of income, 
since he refuses to serve on corporate boards.                       
But his passion is the Carter Center in Atlanta, which raises funds 
for charitable causes 
                      and seeks solutions to problems of war, 
human-rights abuses, and poverty. He and his
                      wife, Rosalynn, have also monitored elections 
in emerging democracies and tried to
                      mediate a number of international disputes. 
-K.T.W.

                      Ronald Reagan, who turned 91 on February 6, has 
become the oldest living
                      ex-president in history. But his advanced 
Alzheimer's makes the story of his twilight
                      years a sad one. Before his condition worsened, 
he was content to watch the
                      passing parade, confident of his place in 
history as the president who helped restore
                      America's confidence and contributed to the end 
of the "evil empire" of communism.
                      Today, he recognizes almost no one and lives in 
seclusion with his wife, Nancy, but
                      their love story is as compelling as ever. A 
friend recently asked Mrs. Reagan if she
                      still sleeps in the same bed as her husband. 
Yes, she said. Wouldn't you get more
                      rest, the friend asked, if you used a rollaway? 
The former first lady wouldn't hear of it.
                      Her husband, she said, might become upset if he 
"rolled over at night and I'm not
                      there." -K.T.W.

                      George Herbert Walker Bush grins as he gazes at 
the ceiling of his Houston office.
                      There dangles a tiny parachutist under a 
billowing chute, a reminder of the former
                      president's adventures a few years back when he 
jumped from a plane to
                      commemorate the moment when he safely bailed 
out of a crippled torpedo bomber in
                      World War II. Bush, 77, always loved the active 
life, but he walks stiffly now because
                      of hip surgery and feels no need to repeat such 
acts of derring-do. In some ways, he
                      is living vicariously through the current 
occupant of the White House. He visits his son
                      there periodically and talks to him regularly 
by phone. But he doesn't give direct advice,
                      just checks in. He travels, raises money for 
cancer research, but almost never makes
                      news. "I don't need to complicate the life of 
the president," he says. -K.T.W.

                      The phone rang around midnight at a reporter's 
home. It was Bill Clinton, responding
                      to a U.S. News request for an interview. (He 
was calling from the West Coast, where
                      it was only 9 p.m., but who's complaining?) He 
was as chatty as ever, rattling off a list
                      of projects he's working on. They include 
writing his memoirs, helping with earthquake
                      relief in India, setting up his presidential 
library, and raising money to help the families
                      of those killed September 11. Clinton, 55, 
believes former presidents have much to
                      contribute: "There's no question [they] can be 
of some help to the country and, if they
                      choose, to the world. . . . But it's a delicate 
thing. You have to find a way to bring your
                      knowledge and experience to bear that is 
appropriate . . . and doesn't, you know,
                      unduly complicate the work of your successor." 
-K.T.W.

title: POST-TRUTH SOCIETY
words:
Post-Truth Society
                      The recent trend of lying is no accident.
                      By Charles Colson | posted 03/04/2002

                      It was the dream of a lifetime for George 
O'Leary: A chance to coach
                      the world's most prestigious football 
teamNotre Dame's Fighting
                      Irish. But the dream soon became a nightmare.

                      The day after he signed his contract with Notre 
Dame, O'Leary's
                      rsum was sent to the pressa rsum that 
included
                      "inaccuracies" about his education and college 
football letters. A few
                      days later, O'Leary resigned in disgrace, the 
victim of his own
                      long-ago lies.

                      It's the latest example of what's become an 
epidemic of lying.

                      In recent years, politicians and pundits, 
professors and even Pulitzer
                      Prizewinners have been caught dealing in 
deceit. One of the nation's
                      most respected historians, Stephen Ambrose, 
plagiarized portions of
                      other historians' works andnotwithstanding his 
public
                      apologyseemed hardly disturbed by the 
resulting controversy.

                      Historian Joseph Ellis, who won the Pulitzer 
Prize for his book,
                      Founding Brothers, was caught inventing a 
Vietnam War record for
                      himself. So was Tim Johnson, manager of the 
Toronto Blue Jays.
                      Ex-conservative writer David Brock admitted 
he'd made up sordid
                      details about Anita Hill. Gloria Steinem's 
claim about the number of
                      women who die of eating disorderssupposedly 
150,000 a
                      yearturned out to be a huge feminist hoax. 
James Patterson and
                      Peter Kim, authors of The Day America Told the 
Truth, estimate that
                      91 percent of us regularly embroider the truth. 
"We lie and don't even
                      think about it," Patterson and Kim write.

                      Why has lying become so much more prevalent? 
Some scholars
                      believe the problem arose out of the gradual 
adoption of a utilitarian
                      ethicone that began eroding the traditional 
Christian ethic in the
                      West in the middle to late 19th century. This 
ethic says the (good)
                      end justifies the meansthat if a lie helps 
more than harms, then we
                      should feel free to employ one.

                      In the late 20th century, the rise of 
postmodern deconstructionism on
                      college campuses exacerbated this problem. 
Postmodernists teach
                      that the truth is not merely irrelevant; they 
believe it simply doesn't
                      exist.

                      As Lynne Cheney observes in her book, Telling 
the Truth, academics
                      "leaped beyond the commonsense observation that 
people's
                      descriptions of reality differ to the 
conclusion that there is no
                      independent reality and thus no basis for 
making judgments about
                      truthor falsity."

                      For these academics, truth claims are "the 
constructs of dominant
                      groupsthe creations of the powerful," Cheney 
writes. "Might makes
                      right, in other words; and so intimidation was 
a perfectly natural way
                      to try to gain assent."

                      The assault on truth has spread beyond academia 
to infect the arts,
                      law, journalism, and psychotherapyand Cheney 
points out the grim
                      results. For instance, when it turned out that 
New York teenager
                      Tawana Brawley had lied about being sexually 
assaulted by white
                      men, The Nation claimed that "it doesn't matter 
whether the crime
                      occurred or not" because it symbolizes "what 
actually happens to too
                      many black women."

                      Those who maintain that truth exists, and that 
telling falsehoods is
                      wrong, are increasingly under assault. "Fact 
fetishists" is how New
                      York University professor Thomas Bender 
characterizes people who
                      insist on accuracy. When reporters hounded him 
about Clintonian
                      lies, thenWhite House aide George 
Stephanopoulos accused them
                      of "an excess of literalism."

                      Postmodernism has filtered down to the masses; 
today, even the
                      man on the street sees little wrong with lying. 
While Washington Post
                      sportswriter Tony Kornheiser agreed that a 
religious college like Notre
                      Dame was "completely right in separating itself 
from George O'Leary,"
                      he argued that "some people" will suggest that 
O'Leary's lies are
                      "insignificant" when compared to his 20-year 
coaching record.

                      In the pages of the New York Post, that's 
exactly what a sports fan
                      did suggest. "I think Notre Dame is acting 
holier than thou," huffed
                      salesman Jim McNulty; O'Leary should be judged 
not on his integrity,
                      but on his coaching record.

                      It's the perfect postmodern answer to lying: 
It's perfectly acceptable to
                      reinvent ourselves, because what we say and do 
matter less than how
                      people perceive us.

                      The good news is that while America's tolerance 
of lying is greater
                      than ever, Americans retain enough of their 
Judeo-Christian ethic that
                      they are still scandalized when a public figure 
lies. We have to help
                      our neighbors understand what's behind the 
current propensity for
                      lying: A worldview that denies the existence of 
truth itself, which
                      merely exacerbates our human fallenness in this 
area. And then we
                      must point them to the Author of truth, the one 
who said, "I am the
                      Way, the Truth, and the Life."


Today International/Christianity Today
                      magazine.

Christianity Today.

title: POST TRAUMATIC STRESS DISORDER
words:
POST TRAUMATIC 
STRESS DISORDER

Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) is a psychiatric diagnosis for 
people who have endured a highly stressful and frightening experience 
and who are experiencing distress caused by memories of that 
experience. It is as if a person is "possessed" by memories of an 
experience and just cannot let go. Because anxiety is the major sign 
of PTSD, it is classified as an anxiety disorder. Other anxiety 
disorders are phobias, panic disorders, and generalized anxiety .

The good news is that it is highly treatable when diagnosed early. 
The bad news is that it is often missed by examining physicians and 
mental health professionals, or it is misdiagnosed as some other 
condition that is more neurobiochemical in nature. But there is no 
drug cure for PTSD.

What causes PTSD?

Catastrophe/traumatic events are the cause of PTSD. These events are 
sudden, overwhelming, and often dangerous, either to one's self or 
significant others(s), such as a car wreck, natural disaster, 
dangerous accident, war combat, robbery at gunpoint, or a near 
drowning; the person affected felt intense fear, helplessness, or 
horror either at the time or immediately afterwards. Close friends, 
family members, and professionals helping those who survive such 
catastrophes can also be affected by trauma. These helpers, because 
of their empathy and compassion for the person in harm's way, can be 
traumatized in the course of providing help.

A catastrophe or traumatic event is a source or cause of stress that 
most people experience. The stress experienced during or immediately 
after the traumatic event or catastrophe is traumatic stress. 
Similarly, the stress that is associated with the traumatic 
event/catastrophe and that is experienced well afterwards is post- 
traumatic stress. It is defined as a set of conscious and unconscious 
behaviors and emotions associated with dealing with the memories of 
the stressors of the catastrophe.

How can you tell if it's PTSD?

Most people who have been exposed to a catastrophe experience both 
traumatic and post-traumatic stress reactions. Most are able to 
survive and cope well; only a small percentage of people develop PTSD.

Authorities recognize four features that all those with PTSD tend to 
exhibit at some time during their illness: the person (a) has been 
exposed to a traumatic event; (b) re-experiences the most traumatic 
aspects of the event; ( c ) makes efforts to cope with these symptoms 
by avoiding exposure to reminders; and ( d) is on edge, unable to 
relax, and unable to think about the event without being obsessed.

Is it possible that there can be a delayed reaction to the traumatic 
event?

Yes. There are three types of PTSD: acute, delayed, and chronic. 
Acute PTSD is when the above symptoms last between one and 3 months 
after the trauma. Chronic PTSD is when the symptoms last for at least 
3 months following the trauma. Delayed PTSD is when symptoms do not 
show up for at least 6 months after the trauma. This is often found 
with adult survivors of childhood traumas.

What are other effects of trauma?

When PTSD is detected, other symptoms and characteristics are found 
too. This is why PTSD is so often misdiagnosed. Among the major sets 
of symptoms are phobia and general anxiety (especially among former 
paws and hostages and natural disaster survivors), substance abuse, 
depression, psychosomatic complaints, an altered sense of time 
(especially among children), grief reactions and obsessions with 
death (especially among those who survived a trauma in which someone 
could have died), feeling guilty , and increased interpersonal 
conflicts. For some who have PTSD, these other features go away once 
the PTSD symptoms are eliminated through treatment.

What kind of help is there for PTSD?  

Both drugs and psychotherapy can be helpful. The most effective 
treatment approaches are called "cognitive- behavioral" because they 
focus both on the way traumatized persons view the trauma and on 
their resulting behavior. Exposure therapy includes systematic 
desensitization (training to relax in the face of frightening 
reminders of the trauma) and imaginable, in-vivo techniques such as 
flooding or the process of putting the client back into the trauma 
psychologically. The most effective treatment for PTSD includes a 
variety of anxiety management training strategies. Some of these 
include Rational Emotive Therapy, various kinds of relaxation 
training, stress innoculation training, cognitive restructuring, 
breathing retraining, biofeedback, social skills training, and 
distraction techniques. Innovative therapists are successful in 
combining various techniques to fit the trauma and the patient's 
unique requirements. 

Families are the best setting to help those who suffer from this 
stress disorder. Families know when a member is acting differently 
than before the traumatic event. A therapist may work with you or 
your family member with PTSD to remember the trauma and reprocess the 
information and mourn losses. This also means that you will learn 
self-soothing techniques and ways to limit the distress during and 
between sessions. Your therapist will help you disconnect from the 
trauma so that reminders do not arouse distress. In doing so, the 
therapist will help you reconnect to life now and in the future 
without being haunted by the trauma. Sometimes this transition to 
life without the trauma is harder than expected.

The reconnecting is especially important: once you are desensitized 
from the burdens caused by the traumatic event, family therapy 
enables you to turn your attention to the future. You will attempt to 
learn from the traumatic events and make needed changes in your 
personal life and relationships, especially love relationships.

What types of drugs might be used in treatment?

For some clients, drug treatment is a useful supplement to effective 
psychotherapy approaches. Drugs such as imipramine, amitriptyline, 
phenelzine, fluoxetine, and propranolol may provide temporary symptom 
relief for general anxiety , depression, insomnia, and related 
problems.
So there is hope for me and my family?

Family therapy offers an extraordinary and useful resource for 
helping families survive a major traumatic event. Social scientists 
have documented the remarkable and consistent patterns of emotional 
recovery from a wide variety of traumatizing events. There is a large 
number of treatment approaches available today. It is impossible to 
prevent traumatic events but family therapy can help promote recovery 
more quickly, and enable family members to get back to what they do 
best: love each other .

---The text for this brochure was written by Charles R. Figley, Ph.D 
and was reprinted with pennission of AAMFT

title: PLEA ON RESTROOM WALL LEADS TO TRUCKER'S ARREST
words:
A woman who was rescued Saturday after a 
maintenance worker found her
                  plea for help on a women's restroom stall told 
police she had been trying
                  for six months to escape the truck driver accused 
of beating her and
                  holding her captive, and had left numerous messages 
in bathrooms.

                  Police found Katina Shaddix, 24, in a truck along 
Interstate 16 in Laurens
                  County, Georgia, about 50 miles east of Macon, said 
Sgt. Gerald Frazier of
                  the Laurens County Sheriff's Department. She 
remained hospitalized
                  Tuesday with fractured ribs, numerous bruises and a 
possible cracked
                  pelvis.

                  The driver, Shannon E. Jones, 26, was charged with 
aggravated assault
                  and was expected to be charged with kidnapping 
Wednesday.

                  Shaddix's plea for help, left on the wall of a 
restroom along Interstate 75 in
                  McMinn County, Tennessee, was found by maintenance 
worker Binford
                  Aycock, who alerted police. Using information in 
her message identifying
                  the truck, augmented with a satellite global 
positioning system, authorities
                  were able to track the truck to Laurens County -- 
about 300 miles from
                  where the message was left.

                  Two deputies found Shaddix in the truck Saturday 
and took Jones into
                  custody, Frazier said. He had made no statements to 
the police Tuesday
                  afternoon, Frazier said.

                  At first, Shaddix told police, she and Jones were 
friends, and they began
                  traveling together about a year ago, Frazier said. 
But about six months ago,
                  when she decided she wanted to leave, he refused to 
let her go, Frazier
                  said.

                  The only time Jones would leave her alone was when 
she went to the
                  bathroom, Shaddix told officers. She left numerous 
messages asking for
                  help in restrooms as the pair traveled, Frazier 
said.

